docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic political candidates have accused their Republican opponents of proposing to cut health benefits for the elderly by hundreds of billions of dollars. The Republicans yell foul, contending that they are not cutting Medicare, only slowing its growth, and that the Democrats are distorting the truth. The first point to note in this mud-slinging is that neither side wins high marks for accuracy. The Republican budgets would cut Medicare. But so would President Clinton, and by nearly as much. But the real issue, which neither side will come clean on, is that Medicare must be cut. It and its cousin, Medicaid, are gobbling up tax revenues and leaving a shrinking amount to deal with all the other problems that government must confront over the next several decades.
docs.abstract: Editorial sorts out the truth and the untruths in the Democrats and Republicans campaign rhetoric on Medicare, a system that must be cut because it is gobbling up tax revenues and leaving shrinking amount to deal with all other problems government must confront over next several decades; says that the Republican plan does not differ greatly from Pres Clinton's but that he has won the debate with voters because he has emerged as the candidate who would put health care for the elderly above a tax cut (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study by researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health says that 31 percent of Americans were without health insurance or had difficulty getting or paying for medical care at some time in the last year. The study, reported yesterday in The Journal of the American Medical Association, involved telephone interviews with 3,993 Americans selected at random.

headline.main: Health Costs Pose Problems For Millions, A Study Finds

docs.abstract: New study by researchers at Harvard School of Public Health finds 31 percent of Americans are without health insurance or had difficulty getting or paying for medical care at some time in last year (M)
